Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Testing a New Concept for the Long-term Build-up to Coronal Mass Ejections
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Principal Investigator (PI) has assembled an international collaboration to test whether coronal mass ejection (CME) build-up can be ascribed to a four-stage process of magnetic field evolution that ultimately leads to the triggering of a CME. This four stage process consists of (1) canceling of magnetic fields along a polarity reversal boundary; (2) formation of a filament channel concurrent with the ascent of horizontal magnetic field into the chromosphere from cancellation sites; (3) thread-by-thread formation of a filament magnetic field and visible filament when the filament channel attains maximum development; and finally, (4) thread-by-thread building of the filament cavity magnetic field as mass drains from the visible threads, thereby incrementally releasing filament magnetic field into the cavity magnetic field until one of many possible triggering mechanisms initiates the CME.

The PI's team will examine these distinct stages and the mechanisms linking them, taking advantage of the synergy offered by new observations, data analysis, numerical modeling, analytic theory, and laboratory plasma experiments. The PI's team expects this project to provide a greatly improved understanding of how CMEs originate and evolve. This improved knowledge of the CME environment is needed to develop predictive tools so that critical space weather events can be accurately forecast.

Our research was centered on the topic of filament channels and filaments which are also called "prominences". We concentrate on the filament environmentááá because filaments erupt concurrently solar flares and when this happens a large volume of mass surrounding an erupting filament also is ejected from the Sun.á By studying the entire environment around filamentsáá we are able to understand why solar flares occur and why large volumes of solar gas (known as plasma) around erupting filaments also erupt. This surrounding envelope of gas is called a "solar mass ejection" and it is this mass ejection that travels through space and has large effects on the EarthÆs magnetic field and upper atmosphere when one of them comes from the Sun in the direction of Earth, interacts with the Earths magnetic field, and causes multiple effect in EarthÆs outer atmosphere.á The combination of an eruptive filament, its associated flare and surrounding coronal mass ejection CME) is known as a "solar eruptive event."
á
Figure 1a illustrates a filament observed from a telescope in the Canary Islands, the Dutch Open Telescope (DOT). Figure 1b and 1c. shows the same filament as seen from two other observatories in space.áá Figure 1d shows the magnetic field at the base of the filament in the solar atmospheric layer called the "photosphere".á Filaments always develop along the boundary between the positive (white) polarity of the magnetic field and the negative polarity (black).
á
A new result from studying the DOT data is our finding of the source of the ever-present counterstreaming mass in filaments. Figure 2 is an enlargement of the area within the white squares in Figure 1d. The orange and red colored threads in the second panel and the blue and green threads in the third panel of Figure 2 are the respective Ha Doppler shifted threads in the filament that are moving away from and toward us as the observers. The threads moving away and those coming toward us are intermingled and this is what is meant by counterstreaming. These threads were copied and superposed on a single magnetogram for the same day and relatively close in time. The fourth panel of Figure 2 shows just the apparent endpoints of the threads with the same color coding as in the other panels. From this panel it is clear that the sources and sink sites of the threads in the filament cluster around the negative polarity that is nearly surrounded by positive polarity (white). The significance of this is that the negative magnetic flux is being continuously cancelled by the positive magnetic flux. All points are not expected to lie precisely at the +/- interface because the interface can be elevated above the photospheric layer in this magnetogram. The implication is that cancelling magnetic fields can be interpreted as an energy source for driving the mass along the threads of the filament. It is known that filament formation invariably begins with cancelling magnetic field; because filament threads are aligned with the local magnetic field, the filaments are also an important means of aiding the interpretation of cancelling magnetic fields. Cancelling fields are interpreted by our team as magnetic reconnection at or close to the photosphere. In this process, the mostly vertical magnetic field is converted to horizontal magnetic field that is above the observed photospheric layer. Because the magnetograms shown only reveal the vertical component of magnetic, the magnetic flux seems to disappear or "cancel".
